instructions.title: Instructions
list: This website is designed for first-year students of the course 01006012 Computer Programming, KMITL.
For optimal display, it is recommended to use Google Chrome or Firefox.
Internet Explorer is not recommended.
Students must write the program on their own device and upload the source code (filename.py) to the system.
After finishing your session, make sure to log out of the system.
For the first login, use your student ID (an 8-digit number) as both the username and password.
After the first login, change your password, complete your profile, and upload a clear photo of your face without a mask.
If you cannot log in, contact your instructor to reset the password.
Students must verify that their group is correct (on the Home page). If it is incorrect, inform your instructor.
Each chapter will have 5 exercises (items), each worth 2 points.
You can submit as many times as needed until your solution is correct. This is to encourage students to practice on their own.
If your submission does not earn points, it may score 0 or -1. However, if it passes, you will receive 2 points per item.
Students cannot log in from two computers at the same time.
The submitted source code will have a timestamp added at the beginning of the file, which does not affect execution.
Commands not included in the lessons are not recommended. If used, students take the risk of their submission not being graded.
After submitting the source code, if it does not pass the test cases, the system will display the first failed case.
Test cases without input display are called hidden test cases.
Instructors can open or close labs at any time.
After studying a lesson, students should complete the lab as soon as possible.
Each chapter's lab will remain open for approximately 7 days.
Submitted source code must not contain the word 'import'.

examination.title: Examination
list: Bring your student ID card or citizen ID card, pencil, and pen.
Students must take the exam at the Department of Computer Engineering.
This is a closed-book exam.
Students will not be able to view their assignment submission history.
This website cannot be accessed from external computer networks outside the institution.
The computers are configured to access only this website. Other websites cannot be accessed.
Once in the room, test the computer. If any equipment is malfunctioning, report it to the staff.
Test the IDE (VS Code) you are using by writing a Hello World program. If it's not working, notify the staff before starting the exam.
Save files on drive D or E.
If the computer is restarted, any unsaved data will be lost.
No documents are allowed inside the exam room.
Do not bring electronic devices. Turn off the devices and place them in a safe location.
If cheating is detected, penalties will be imposed according to the regulations of the Faculty of Engineering.
Sign in before the exam and sign out after the exam.

list.title: What should a student do if they want to change groups?
list.desc: They need to inform the instructor about which group they are switching from.

list.title: How many times can I submit the lab?
list.desc: You can submit the lab as many times as needed until you get a full score.

list.title: Why does the score change after submitting a full score and going back again?
list.desc: This is because the system rechecks the submission every time you view the details. If there are changes in the problem or test case, it will affect your score.

list.title: What should I do if I forget my password?
list.desc: Contact the instructor to reset your password.

list.title: What is a hidden test case?
list.desc: A test case that is not shown on the screen intentionally. If it fails, read the problem again and analyze it thoroughly.

list.title: What should I do if I fail a hidden test case?
list.desc: Go back and read the problem carefully. If you don't understand, consult the instructor.

list.title: Can I use commands outside of what has been taught?
list.desc: No, all the problems are designed to be solved using only the commands taught or specified in the problem. It is not recommended to use commands beyond what has been covered.

list.title: Why is import not allowed?
list.desc: 1. Imports are unnecessary for basic operations. 2. Using imports complicates the lessons. 3. Using imports without understanding could lead to errors.

list.title: What is the maximum size of the output for a test case?
list.desc: The output size should not exceed 1 MB.

list.title: Why is there no test case output?
list.desc: Check the input. The number of inputs must match the problem requirements.

list.title: Can I submit a new file after I get a full score?
list.desc: Yes, you can, but you need to inform the instructor and provide a reason.

list.title: The test passes on my machine but fails when submitted, what should I do?
list.desc: Check the Python version, check for case sensitivity, and verify any extra spaces between characters.
